Review: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf

Joe Lichtenstein brings Edward Albee's contentious drama to life with enthralling results. Lily Grant reviews.

Review: An evening with Gary Lineker

An exploration of the role of football in society, 'An evening with Gary Lineker' sees an effective combination of subversive humour and accurate social commentary. Ben Cross reviews.

Review: Wild East

TFTV's latest offering 'Wild East' is a captivating piece which kept the intimate venue on tenterhooks throughout. Lucie Parker reviews. (Thumbnail credit (c)Wild East)

Review: Othello

With Othello being one of Shakespeare's most revered creations, the producer of York's latest interpretation of the play had the chance to do something new with it. Sadly, France's production did not take this opportunity, leaving reviewers Celia Scruby and Mary O'Connor wholly underwhelmed.

Best Book: Merivel, A Man Of His Time by Rose Tremain

As always with Tremain, her new book is masterfully written. Merivel is a triumph, says James Metcalf.

Review: URY O'Sullivan and Mawn

A few teething problems aside, O'Sullivan and Mawn's new radio show is genuinely brilliant.

Best Book

The term 'thriller' doesn't often go together with 'literary', but here the two collide in S. J. Watson's phenomenal debut novel

Editor's Picks

Oscar Wilde's 1895 comedy, <strong>The Importance of Being Earnest</strong> in Week 9 finishes off a diverse and successful summer term at the Barn...

Deputy Editor's Picks

Shakespeare's <strong>A Midsummer Night's Dream</strong> comes to the barn this week. Directed by Rosie Fletcher, this iconic and much parodied tale of love, deceit, fairies and asses, faces the challenge of creating something innovative

Editor's Picks

A variety of arts events which can appeal to everyone are coming up over the next couple of weeks. For those of you with a hectic schedule: most are right here on campus, so don't miss out
